awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Traditional Institutions and the Modern State
awd_abstract_narration:
Mayors of some rural municipalities in Latin America have only limited revenue to produce infrastructural projects, but they can sometimes compensate for this dearth of resources by partnering with leaders of communal landholding institutions, or communities which operate at the sub-district level. Community leaders can mobilize unpaid labor from community members through traditional institutions called "labor corvees." Through collaboration with these leaders, mayors can provide public works more efficiently by avoiding the highest input cost for infrastructure projects' labor, and using the resources of the municipality, community leaders can provide higher quality public works for their communities.  Despite the potential benefits for both sides, such cooperation has become increasingly rare. This project examines the conditions under which these cooperative arrangements emerge, focusing specifically on the strategic interaction between community leaders and mayors. The proposed research contributes to a long-standing debate in political science on whether traditional and state institutions substitute for or complement one another. This research develops a theoretical framework that reconciles these two approaches, showing the conditions under which states and traditional institutions are complements as opposed to substitutes. In contrast to much of the existing literature on this topic, which relies heavily on qualitative and observational data, the work uses field experiments and natural experiments to evaluate the theory. More broadly, the results of this research will shed light on causes of intra-district inequality. Communities have varying levels of access to the local government and its resources, and this project will shed light on important sources of this inequality. A deeper understanding of these dynamics may assist central governments globally in targeting programs and resources to areas that are not normally prioritized by, or accessible to, local state officials.

This project examines the conditions under which states reinforce or undermine traditional institutions. An early literature on the subject argued that state institutions would either crowd out or mostly disrupt traditional institutions. A separate literature, which is more recent, has argued that traditional and state institutions are complementary, and that through cooperation or delegation, state officials can take advantage of opportunities presented by traditional institutions. This project develops a theoretical framework that attempts to reconcile these two approaches by examining when cooperative relationships emerge between state officials and leaders of traditional institutions. To explore this question, the study uses two main strategies. First, it exploits a natural experiment from early twentieth century in Peru to test how variation in initial exposure to state institutions affected the long-term persistence of traditional institutions of unpaid labor. Second, the study uses a regression kink design with contemporary data to examine when mayors direct state resources to traditional institutions of unpaid labor. To supplement these analyses of main effects and to test for mechanisms, the author relies on a multi-method strategy, which includes archival research, interviews with state officials and community leaders, a field experiment with over 100 mayors, and a conjoint experiment and behavioral game with over 300 current and former community presidents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Christopher Carter studies the relationship between indigenous institutions and the central state in Latin America. The National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant funded research to investigate a specific component of this research agenda. Specifically, the project funded a telephone survey, which included an experimental component, administered with over 1,000 indigenous Bolivians in spring 2021. The goal of this survey was to understand when indigenous communities support reforms that recognize their traditional institutions.

Carter's dissertation aims to understand when indigenous groups seek recognition for their longstanding indigenous institutions. One of the central cases is Bolivia, where a 2009 constitutional reform granted indigenous communities the option to pursue autonomous status. If most voters in an indigenous-majority municipality vote in favor of adopting autonomy, a meeting is convened in which residents draft a new municipal constitution that replaces state institutions with those of indigenous groups. A well-developed and interdisciplinary literature predicts that native communities will universally embrace these autonomy-increasing reforms. Yet, to date, only three Bolivian municipalities--out of over 200 eligible ones--have adopted autonomous status. To address this puzzling rejection of autonomy by many indigenous communities in Bolivia, Carter fielded a survey with over 1,000 indigenous Bolivians.

The survey and experiment yielded two key findings, which confirmed two key hypotheses from Carter’s dissertation. First, prior experiences with state-led extraction (i.e., state efforts to take indigenous land, labor, and natural or financial wealth) shape indigenous communities' decisions to pursue autonomy. Generally, state-led extraction increases the likelihood that communities will pursue autonomy. Specifically, state interference in indigenous communities reduces affected communities' confidence in the state, leading them to substitute traditional institutions for those of the government. The survey and experiment confirm that communities that have experienced state-led extraction view autonomy more favorably. This relationship becomes stronger when respondents are informed of the benefits of autonomy for reducing extractive practices. 

A second hypothesis holds that a key source of resistance to autonomy emerges from a fear that embracing indigenous institutions will result in reduced access to government resources. The data from the experiment supports this expectation. Among the full sample of respondents, the costs of autonomy are weighed more highly than the benefits it may provide. Specifically, respondents become more opposed to autonomy when they learn that autonomous status has resulted in a decline in municipal revenues in autonomous municipalities. In contrast, among the full sample, varying the benefits of autonomy did not have a substantial effect on respondents’ likelihood of supporting autonomous status for their municipality: respondents were not more favorable toward autonomy after learning of its potential benefits for either environmental protection or staving off extraction by outsiders.

The findings thus demonstrate that the individual-level decision to support autonomy arises from both historical experiences and the projected impacts of autonomous status. Prior experiences with extraction by central states increase the likelihood that indigenous individuals support autonomy. However, the potential costs of autonomy in terms of foregone local resources are also salient. Indigenous communities often worry about autonomy reducing their local governments' access to needed state-provided goods, services, and financial resources.  That costs are important for the full sample of respondents and benefits important for only a subset may shed light on why so few eligible indigenous municipalities have--to date--adopted autonomy in Bolivia.
